comments.text:
+Ramin Honary Lets examine the three systems of economic organization:

• Free Enterprise, where capital goods are owned by private owners and 
controlled by private owners,
• Fascism, where capital goods are owned by private owners and controlled 
by the state,
• Socialism, where capital goods are owned by the state and controlled by 
the state.
 
These 3 systems are separate constructs from the four forms of government:
 
• Anarchy (rule by no one,) (Examples of this are called Failed States)
• Dictatorship or Monarchy (rule by one person,) 
• Oligarchy (rule by a few persons, like we currently have here,) We call 
it a Republic, a Constitutional Monarchy, a Confederation or a Federation.
• Democracy (rule by the majority, aka "tyranny of the masses") We call 
this doing things by Plebiscite. It quickly becomes unwieldy unless you 
have an intelligent and educated populace (not on this planet.)
 
None of these socio-economic systems are mutually exclusive in the larger 
context of a political systems.
 
In fact, it is necessary to combine the three because there are features of 
each which complement and fill in the blind spots in each.
 
A successful country is one where the systems are successfully blended.
 
An unsuccessful country is one where there is an unnecessary bias towards 
one or another.
 
For example, that is why we have a unified power grid but each 
utility/corporation cooperates in maintaining the unified power grid while 
trying to minimize the costs, possibly to maximize their profitability.
 
This cooperative feature is arrived at regardless of the economic system or 
political system.
 
Our economic problems arise from a misunderstanding of what a politicians 
jobs were by our oligarchies (the people some, not all but merely some of 
us, held our noses and elected.)

top_comment.text:
*US Is an Oligarchy Not a Democracy, says Scientific Study*
*by Eric Zuesse | Monday, April 14, 2014*
https://www.commondreams.org/view/2014/04/14

A study, to appear in the Fall 2014 issue of the academic journal 
Perspectives on Politics, finds that the U.S. is no democracy, but instead 
an oligarchy, meaning profoundly corrupt, so that the answer to the study’s 
opening question, "Who governs? Who really rules?" in this country, is: 

"Despite the seemingly strong empirical support in previous studies for 
theories of majoritarian democracy, our analyses suggest that majorities of 
the American public actually have little influence over the policies our 
government adopts. Americans do enjoy many features central to democratic 
governance, such as regular elections, freedom of speech and association, 
and a widespread (if still contested) franchise. But, ..." and then they go 
on to say, it's not true, and that, "America's claims to being a democratic 
society are seriously threatened" by the findings in this, the first-ever 
comprehensive scientific study of the subject, which shows that there is 
instead "the nearly total failure of 'median voter' and other Majoritarian 
Electoral Democracy theories [of America]. When the preferences of economic 
elites and the stands of organized interest groups are controlled for, the 
preferences of the average American appear to have only a minuscule, 
near-zero, statistically non-significant impact upon public policy."

To put it short: The United States is no democracy, but actually an 
oligarchy.

The authors of this historically important study are Martin Gilens and 
Benjamin I. Page, and their article is titled "Testing Theories of American 
Politics." The authors clarify that the data available are probably 
under-representing the actual extent of control of the U.S. by the 
super-rich:

Economic Elite Domination theories do rather well in our analysis, even 
though our findings probably understate the political influence of elites. 
Our measure of the preferences of wealthy or elite Americans – though 
useful, and the best we could generate for a large set of policy cases – is 
probably less consistent with the relevant preferences than are our 
measures of the views of ordinary citizens or the alignments of engaged 
interest groups. Yet we found substantial estimated effects even when using 
this imperfect measure. The real-world impact of elites upon public policy 
may be still greater.
Nonetheless, this is the first-ever scientific study of the question of 
whether the U.S. is a democracy. "Until recently it has not been possible 
to test these contrasting theoretical predictions [that U.S. policymaking 
operates as a democracy, versus as an oligarchy, versus as some mixture of 
the two] against each other within a single statistical model. This paper 
reports on an effort to do so, using a unique data set that includes 
measures of the key variables for 1,779 policy issues." That’s an enormous 
number of policy-issues studied.

What the authors are able to find, despite the deficiencies of the data, is 
important: the first-ever scientific analysis of whether the U.S. is a 
democracy, or is instead an oligarchy, or some combination of the two. The 
clear finding is that the U.S. is an oligarchy, no democratic country, at 
all. American democracy is a sham, no matter how much it's pumped by the 
oligarchs who run the country (and who control the nation's "news" media). 
The U.S., in other words, is basically similar to Russia or most other 
dubious "electoral" "democratic" countries. We weren't formerly, but we 
clearly are now. Today, after this exhaustive analysis of the data, “the 
preferences of the average American appear to have only a minuscule, 
near-zero, statistically non-significant impact upon public policy.” That's 
it, in a nutshell.﻿

comments.text:
+Thomas Price
I'm not sure if user +Guernicaman is serious about their confusion, is 
making a joke, or both (I'd suspect and prefer both); but I at least share 
that question.  The difference in definition between an "oligarchy" and a 
"plutocracy" is in whether the ruling class is comprised of merely a small 
group of people or if it is specifically comprised up of wealthy people.  
It is a subtle distinction as wealth alone might not determine one's 
influence and power, especially if you control for age (younger and "new" 
members of the ruling class may have yet to make a fortune). 
But on the other hand there is "affluenza"...  and that it is not an 
isolated case.  However, as the wealthy have typically always had influence 
over the criminal justice system (at least until the time of pitchforks and 
guillotines), at what point would such influence become a symptom of a 
plutocracy? 
In the end, I actually leaned towards "Oligarchy," lol.  :-p
Perhaps, though, it is a plutocratic oligarchy? 
But the wealthy are really *extremely* wealthy, such that even though the 
american median income is above the international top 1% level, the 
american national 1%ers average so much much money that from their 
perspective, we are all indistinguishable from the poor of the poorest 
countries.

phone companies. That would include AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile, etc, and 
several smaller ones, all serving several locations simultaneously, but 
other areas individually, even acting as a monopoly in some places.

It is also fair to say that the US, as one example, has an oligarchy system 
in that there are two major political parties that are sure to win the 
majority of elections, while many others are incapable of gaining a 
majority of votes but are in no way prohibited from trying.

Some are of the opinion that oligarchies are always wrong, but that is too 
simplistic a view. If competition is real between two companies, then it 
does not really matter that they are the only two companies capable of 
providing the good or service desired. If the competition is false because 
of some collusion between the two companies, that is bad, but it is also 
possible for ten or 100 companies to also collude for the same reasons that 
two would.

Sorry, at least from where I am from, federal income tax doesn't even pay

for others who pay less. I am not against charity, but this forced legal

And let's not pretend the federal roads are actually necessary. If that 
property were privatized, it's very likely entrepreneurs would have built 
something similar. We cannot predict what would have occurred in an actual 
market without government intrusions as they currently exist today. For all 
we know, we'd be using a lot more air travel to go between cities and such, 
and with more wide-spread use, it would have created a greater demand for 
solving problems in that space. The point is, you can't possibly know what 
would have happened without the federal roads, and in all likelihood, the 
services provided by the market would at least be the same and would likely 
be better to what we have now. Your argument cannot hinge on the idea that 
everything would exist exactly as it does today but without roads if we 
didn't pay more income tax to fund roads. An entirely different outcome 
would have happened instead.

government not supplying roads or other services, then seriously, you

comments.author: Dakota Sanchez

comments.text:
+Dakota Sanchez
One chief reason central banks exist is to inflate the money supply so that 
the national debt is easier to pay off and so governments can spend money 
it really doesn't have so that it can push forth whatever programs or war 
it wants.

This inflation reduces the purchasing power of each dollar everyone has, 
which means everyone is being looted from to pay off the debt, even if this 
theft is not in the form of a tax or something tangible. The interest 
payments you receive on your money while its held inside of a bank is often 
much lower than the rate of inflation, so you can never beat it. You will 
always lose purchasing power, unless you invest that money into something 
that earns you more purchasing power compared to the rate of inflation.

Most of this debt is caused by things you probably didn't consent to. Wars 
you didn't want being faught. Programs you didn't agree with. You're paying 
for a whole wad of crap you didn't consent to, and on top of this, because 
the government couldn't possibly tax you enough, they have to inflate the 
money supply too, which further hurts you.

The debt, at this point, is enormous, and all of us are somehow expected to 
pay off at some point. The unborn clearly have no hope of paying off the 
unpaid stuff from the previous generations, and yet will be enslaved to pay 
for it, just as we are - but they will have it worse.

This all covered by the topic of monetizing debt.

And because banks can simply ask for inflated currency that they loan to 
you - money that you are expected to pay interest on even though the bank 
does not have to pay interest - also makes you a slave to the bankers. They 
profit by essentially doing nothing at all - just putting some numbers into 
a computer - while you have to work hard to pay off the interest on 
whatever loan you take. This is what fractional reserve banking is, and 
central banks have made this possible to such an extreme extent that 
otherwise would not have been made possible.

This, plus the introduction of the income tax - which became permanent with 
the introduction of the federal reserve system in 1913, has caused all of 
us to become slaves of each other, and to whoever has power within the 
country. When you want some government program that is not included in the 
constitution, everyone has to slave away a % of their working life to pay 
for it, whether they agree with it or not - and whether they ultimately use 
it or not.

Since most of the income tax pays off the debt and doesn't actually pay for 
many other services you may benefit from, you are literally slaving a large 
% of your life away to others for nothing.

If all of this doesn't convince you that you are actually a slave, then I 
am envious because you can live life in bliss.

comments.text:
Your vote goes towards an elector who, in turn, typically votes for a 
candidate to who they pledged. If enough of the electorate vote for your 
candidate of choice, he/she will be elected. During his/her term, the 
candidate will typically work in favor of the policies that he/she 
advertised during his/her election campaign, thus allowing your voice to be 
heard. 

If a politician strays away from his/her promised policies, it's usually on 
a matter of principle (ex. when Bush 43 adopted a neoconservative foreign 
policy when he had previously favored a non-interventionist approach). Very 
rarely can one find a hard instance of a politician voting in favor of a 
bill because of the financial contributions of one of his donors.

top_comment.text:
Oligarchy is a very heavy, loaded word. It is seldom thrown around bereft 
of any undertones of conspiracy or 1984-themed empty glass outlooks on the 
world. Because of this, we have come to associate it as such. We've come to 
see it as a word that carries the same stigma as words like "Orwell" or 
"Dystopia" - a synonym for some hypothetical future, the way things might 
be in a non-existent parody of the way things are. Never does it hit home 
that this is literally exactly the way things are. No conspiracy theory, no 
tin foil hats. Seriously. The definition of that words applies, now, to the 
way things actually work. We have crossed that line, because we have all 
fictionalized it so much we never imagined it might actually happen.

This IS the dystopian future. This is what we have been fearing, and what 
we never let ourselves believe could actually happen.﻿

comments.text:
+james taylor We need change and we need it fast, but to use Scientific 
Socialist terms, we don't need "revolution"--we need evolution. Capitalism 
didn't come into being by revolution, but rather by societal change; 
Socialism has to come into power the same way. Revolution is often just a 
change of flag: the French and Russian Revolutions both took their 
respective nations from one dictatorship to another. The American 
Revolution turned out differently, but a war for independence is different 
from a true revolution.

Consider this: What's more effective, a speech or a bomb? The speech. So 
what's more effective, violence or diplomacy? Diplomacy. Many have turned 
to violence because of its immediate effect. Unfortunately, the effect is 
transient. If you consider France again, you will consider that it's most 
stable phase (The Fifth Republic--modern France) was brought about 
peacefully (yes, it followed WWII, but it was not a *direct* result of war).

This reasoning is mostly that of Enrico Ferri, an Italian Socialist from 
the turn of the century. If you're interested read his piece "The 
Revolutionary Method" (it's available on marxists.org).

comments.text:
The United States like many other countries has evolved its government 
through its life time to present.
At the beginning it was a constitutional republic federation of states. 
 With mostly all the power to the states and any democratic election to its 
republics decided on by the states. It was economically and politically 
chaotic, so the Constitutional federal Government was created to oversea 
all states, the one Washington was elected by congress to be president (our 
first US president under the constitution). 
Most of all the elected bodies to the federal government was voted into 
office by peers elected from states, only under state level were male white 
property owners allowed to vote for their state representatives or run for 
office.

-Then times changed by 1830's all white males could vote for state 
candidates regardless of property ownership.
-Then all males regardless of race could vote. Black suffrage was later 
extended to all states by the 15th Amendment (ratified in 1870)
-Then the people could vote directly for their federal representatives 
(senate candidates) not just for their state representation who would elect 
the federal representation. The Seventeenth Amendment (Amendment XVII) to 
the United States Constitution established direct election of United States 
Senators by popular vote
-1920 women could vote. The Nineteenth Amendment (Amendment XIX)
Then women and men could vote for their state representatives.
- Bringing the vote to people under 21 years of age wasn't fully adopted in 
all states until 1971. The 26th Amendment ratified by in 1971, voting age 
became in all states 18 years old or older.

So its been an evolving process.  At the start basically for elite property 
owners with most votes from within the states elected bodies who then 
elected federal candidates to federal positions. Kind of like today 
regarding the electoral college. They did this for a few reasons, the 
elites didn't trust the uneducated mob for higher authority of government, 
many were actually couldn't even read in the 18th and 19th century.  And of 
course, to maintain their businesses (their wealth) and political authority 
just like any elites do in any social structure. Human nature.

  Because what was written at the beginning was a power too and for a few 
wealthy white men, a plutocrat. And has evolved into more of a democratic 
republic as far as the federal government. As for states, each state acts 
different. Some states like mine in Idaho, require popular vote to approve 
their state legislature to raise any state taxes or to give any authority 
for taxes or establishing any governmental state authority. Essentially, 
Idaho, as other states, many state laws passed by legislature must be 
ratified by popular vote by the people.  So its a complex subject depending 
whether you're talking about state or federal government, and which state. 
Then what time period.
All happened at various times by states and eventually adopted by all 
states usually by constitutional amendments. All from protests, riots, 
rebellions to outright civil war. The founding fathers only stroke of 
genius was to keep the constitution vague and open for updates. And it has 
been updated quite a bit.
 And needs lots more updates. 
Below is source of timeline regarding democratic vote of the people.
http://www.nationalpopularvote.com/resources/Constiutionality-V6-2010-3-7.pdf
